Graphical abstract Highlights ► Tetramethylammonium trimetallates were obtained by mechanical grinding route. ► Layer and stacking degree of sulfides showed a decreasing trend with increasing Ni content. ► Low Ni content showed greatly enhanced intrinsic catalytic activity per unit surface area. ► The addition of nickel promoted the hydrogenation pathway in the HDS of DBT. A family of unsupported NiMoW sulfide catalysts have been prepared by thermal decomposition of mechanically ground tetramethylammonium thiomolybdotungstate and Ni(NO3)2 for hydrodesulfurization of dibenzothiophene. The materials were characterized by Fourier transformation infrared spectroscopy, ultraviolet–visible spectroscopy, thermogravimetric analysis, X-ray diffraction, N2 physorption, scanning electron microscopy, and transmission electron microscopy. The results showed that structures and properties of unsupported NiMoW sulfides depend on nickel content and decomposition condition. XRD revealed a decrease in the stacking along the c direction of the MoS2 and/or WS2 crystalline structures as the nickel content was increased, consistent with a higher dispersion of the metal sulfides observed by electron microscopy. The low nickel content in Ni0.5MoWS y catalyst gave a positive effect on the hydrodesulfurization of dibenzothiophene, as indicated by the greatly increased specific catalytic activity per unit surface area. In contrast, the high nickel content in Ni1.5MoWS y catalyst showed a negative effect due to the formation of nickel sulfides. Ni0.5MoWS y catalyst showed the highest activity in the hydrodesulfurization reaction compared to other samples. The results further suggest that unsupported NiMoW sulfide catalysts may be promising candidates for wide application in hydrotreating of fuel oil. Keywords Unsupported NiMoW sufides Thermal decomposition Hydrodesulfurization Dibenzothiophene Thiosalts 1 Introduction More and more stringent environmental regulations and fuel specifications are requiring a significant reduction of sulfur and nitrogen containing compounds, as well as aromatics, in fuels. Hydrotreating processes such as hydrodesulfurization (HDS), hydrodenitrogenation and hydrodearomatization are considered as some of the most cost-effective routes to simultaneously remove sulfur, nitrogen and aromatics from fuels. The conventional hydrotreating process is performed over alumina supported sulfide catalysts based on Mo or W and promoted with Ni or Co. These materials are usually produced by sulﬁdation of the corresponding metal oxides. However, it is well accepted that incomplete sulﬁdation due to strong interaction between metal and support results in non-optimal hydrotreating activity [1]. Recently, unsupported sulfide catalysts have attracted much attention due to their high activity for hydrotreating reactions. A number of methods, including comaceration [2], homogeneous sulfide precipitation [3], thiosalt decomposition [4–6], hydrothermal and solvothermal processes [7–11] and solution reactions [12,13], have been developed to prepare unsupported sulfide catalysts. The structures and catalytic properties of these sulfides strongly depend on their preparation and treatment conditions [2,3,10]. Thiosalt decomposition provides a simple and reproducible method for obtaining unsupported binary and ternary sulfides with controlled stoichiometry and wide ranges of specific surface areas [14–16]. Limited reports have also focused on preparation and hydrotreating properties of the unsupported quaternary sulfide catalysts [17–22]. The development of the new NEBULA catalysts, which are three times more active than the ones conventionally used in industry, has spurred research regarding unsupported trimetallic HDS catalysts. For example, Soled et al. [17] have synthesized trimetallic NiMoW sulfides by sulfidization of the corresponding trimetallic oxide precursors. Nava et al. [18] prepared unsupported NiMoW sulfides by decomposition of alkylthiomolybdotungstates, and found that the alkyl group strongly affected the speciﬁc surface area and HDS activity of these materials. Bocarando et al. [19] reported the synthesis of unsupported trimetallic NiMoW catalysts by decomposition of ammonium thiomolybdotungstates, and suggested that the nickel addition led to high speciﬁc surface area and catalytic activity. Based on these studies, there is still much to understand regarding the relationship between precursor structure, and the structure and performance of the resulting unsupported catalysts. In this work, unsupported trimetallic NiMoW sulfides with different Ni content were prepared by ex situ decomposition of tetramethylammonium thiomolybdotungstates and Ni(NO3)2 mixtures prepared by mechanical grinding. It was hypothesized that these precursors would provide an effective and reproducible alternative method for obtaining superior catalysts having mesoporous structure with good HDS catalytic properties. Extensive structural characterization and evaluation for the HDS of dibenzothiophene revealed that structure and catalytic performance of these novel unsupported NiMoW sulfides depend strongly on nickel content and decomposition condition. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation The MoW sulfide precursor tetramethylammonium thiomolybdotungstate was synthesized according to the following reactions: (1) 12 7 ( NH 4 ) 6 Mo 7 O 24 + ( NH 4 ) 6 H 2 W 12 O 40 ⟶ H 2 O , NH 4 OH , H 2 S 12 ( NH 4 ) 4 MoWS 8 (2) ( NH 4 ) 4 MoWS 8 + ( CH 3 ) 4 NCl → [ N ( CH 3 ) 4 ] 4 MoWS 8 + NH 4 Cl In detail, 1.8g hexaammonium heptamolybdate tetrahydrate ((NH4)6Mo7O24) and 2.5g ammonium metatungstate hydrate ((NH4)6H2W12O40) were dissolved in 30ml aqueous ammonia. The pH of the solution was found to be constant at around 10.0 during the preparation procedures. Hydrogen sulfide was bubbled into the solution under stirring condition at 70°C. About 6h later, after adding aqueous solution of tetramethylammonium chloride and sodium hydroxide, red tetramethylammonium thiomolybdotungstate crystal ([N(CH3)4]4MoWS8) was formed. Then [N(CH3)4]4MoWS8 was obtained through filtration and drying. This methodology is a modification of previous reported synthesis procedure in the literature to prepare [N(CH3)4]4MoWS8 [23]. The key difference in the present case is the simultaneous mixing of the oxide precursors in the same solution, and use of a tetramethylammonium chloride. This modified procedure results in high [N(CH3)4]4MoWS8 yield. In order to prepare the NiMoW sulfides with Ni:Mo:W molar ratios of 0:1:1, 0.5:1:1, 1:1:1 and 1.5:1:1, the precursors of [N(CH3)4]4MoWS8 and appropriate amount of nickel nitrate were mixed by mechanical grinding method. For this procedure, the materials were ground in a mortar and pestle for 3min, at which point the resulting powder was greater than 80 mesh. These precursors were named as [N(CH3)4]4MoWS8, Ni0.5[N(CH3)4]4MoWS8, Ni[N(CH3)4]4MoWS8 and Ni1.5[N(CH3)4]4MoWS8, respectively. The unsupported NiMoW sulfide catalysts were prepared by thermal decomposition of the above precursors in a tubular reactor. The precursors were heated from room temperature to 400°C at a rate of 3°Cmin−1 under 60cm3 min−1 argon and kept at the temperature for 4h. The as-prepared samples were labeled as MoWS y , Ni0.5MoWS y , NiMoWS y and Ni1.5MoWS y , respectively. 2.2 Characterization Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were collected at room temperature on a Nicolet Impact 410 with a resolution of 4cm−1. Samples were tested after being mixed with finely divided KBr. The ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis) spectra were recorded on a UV–vis spectrometer (JASCO V-550). A home-made Raman spectrometer with a IK-Series Helium cadmium laser source (325nm) was used for recording Raman spectra of the samples. The power of the laser line at the sample was below 3mW. An Acton triple monochromator was used as a spectrometer to collect Raman scattered light, and the spectra were recorded using a Princeton CCD detector. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed using a Mettler Toledo TGA/SDTA851e instrument under nitrogen from room temperature to 450°C at a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1 in order to determine decomposition behavior of the as-prepared precursor. Speciﬁc surface area (SSA) measurements were performed on a Micromeritics 2010 instrument by nitrogen adsorption at −196°C using the BET isotherm while the pore size distribution was calculated by N2 adsorption using the Barrett–Joyner–Hallenda (BJH) method. The mean standard deviation for SSA measurements was about 2%. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis of the samples was carried out using a Rigaku D/Max-RB diffractometer with a Cu Kα monochromatized radiation source (λ =1.54178Å), operated at 40kV and 100mA. The morphologies of the as-prepared samples were studied in a scanning electron microscope (SEM, JEOL JSM-5600LV), operated at 15kV. Particle size and distribution of the samples were studied using a Philips CM200 FEG transmission electron microscope (TEM), operated at 200kV. Elemental mapping was conducted under scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) mode with the energy dispersion X-ray spectrum (EDX) detector as recorder. 2.3 HDS of dibenzothiophene HDS of dibenzothiophene (DBT) was carried out in continuous mode in a fixed-bed reactor as described elsewhere [24]. A 0.05g sample of passivated NiMoW sulfide catalysts was diluted with quartz to achieve isothermal plug-flow conditions. The catalyst was activated in situ in H2 (60mlmin−1) at 340°C for 0.5h to remove the passivation layer. The sulfide catalyst had been previously passivated by exposure to air at room temperature after the thermal decomposition. After activation, the pressure was increased to 3.0MPa and the temperature was kept at 340°C for the HDS reaction. The liquid reactant was fed into the reactor by a high-pressure pump. The composition of the liquid feed was 94.7wt.% decalin as solvent, 0.3wt.% n-octane (gas chromatograph reference for DBT and its derivatives), and 5wt.% DBT. The reaction products were analyzed on a gas chromatograph (GC 7890F) with a ﬂame ionization detector and a SE-54/52 capillary column. A modified plug-flow reactor model was used to calculate the surface area normalized (i.e., specific) rate constant: k ′ = F m × SSA × ln ( 1 − X ) where k’ is defined as rate constant (mols−1 m−2), F is DBT molar flow (mols−1), m is catalyst mass (g), SSA is catalyst specific surface area (m2 g−1), and X is the conversion of DBT. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of [N(CH3)4]4MoWS8 precursor Prior to the preparation of unsupported MoW and NiMoW catalysts, it is necessary to confirm that the synthesis procedure described in Section 2.1 indeed yielded [N(CH3)4]4MoWS8. Fig. 1 shows the UV–vis spectra of [N(CH3)4]4MoWS8, [N(CH3)4]2MoS4 and [N(CH3)4]2WS4. There are four main absorption bands in both [N(CH3)4]2MoS4 and [N(CH3)4]2WS4 that correspond to tetrahedral MoS4 2− and WS4 2−. For [N(CH3)4]2MoS4, the absorption bands appeared at 447, 306, 235, and 213nm, while [N(CH3)4]2WS4 exhibited at 453, 378, 269, and 212nm [24]. In the case of [N(CH3)4]4MoWS8, there were five main absorption bands that appeared at 447, 398, 306, 235, and 210nm. The main bands in [N(CH3)4]4MoWS8 are similar with those in the tetrahedral MoS4 2− and WS4 2−. However, the adsorption band at 398nm had a shift to high wavelength compared with 378nm band corresponding to WS4 2−. This may be attributed to metal–metal interaction between Mo and W, although further study is required to confirm this. FT-IR spectra of [N(CH3)4]4MoWS8, [N(CH3)4]2WS4 and [N(CH3)4]2MoS4 are presented in Fig. 2 . The present tetramethylammonium thiosalts showed Mo–S and W–S stretching bands at 474 and 459cm−1, respectively [25]. The importance of the detection of these Mo–S or W–S bonds in [N(CH3)4]4MoWS8 is that they are almost identical in frequency to those corresponding metal sulfur stretches in [N(CH3)4]2WS4 and [N(CH3)4]2MoS4, confirming the formation of these bonds. Moreover, the [N(CH3)4]4MoWS8 presents complex bands at 2900–3000 and 1460–1480cm−1, which are assigned to aliphatic C–H and ammonium groups, respectively. Fig. 3 shows Raman spectra of [N(CH3)4]4MoWS8, [N(CH3)4]2WS4 and [N(CH3)4]2MoS4. The spectrum of [N(CH3)4]2MoS4 (middle) shows the characteristic bands of the MoS4 2− anion at 426cm−1 and 190cm−1 due to Mo–S and S–Mo–S vibrations, respectively. The 426cm−1 vibration is extremely weak, and interestingly is very different than the stretching frequency observed in the FT-IR spectrum (474cm−1, Fig. 2). This suggests that this vibration arises from a different Mo–S vibration in this precursor. Compared with [N(CH3)4]2MoS4, the spectrum for [N(CH3)4]2WS4 (bottom) exhibits bands at 462cm−1 and 178cm−1, arising from W–S [26] and S–W–S vibrations, respectively. The strong 462cm−1 band is very similar in frequency to that observed in the FT-IR spectra (459cm−1, Fig. 2). For the mixed metal [N(CH3)4]4MoWS8 (top), a new single metal-S vibration is observed at 434cm−1 and the other vibrations are not observed. This may be indicative of a sulfur atom coordinated to Mo that is modified by W (or the reverse), although this explanation is at present speculative. Nevertheless, taken together the above spectroscopic results (summarized in Table 1 ) suggest that the mixed metal [N(CH3)4]4MoWS8 precursor has indeed been successfully prepared. Further vibrational studies of these precursors, along with complementary theoretical calculations of structure and vibrational modes and frequencies, are planned in order to more precisely determine the nature of this mixed MoW precursor. 3.2 Decomposition of MoW and NiMoW precursors Following the precursor spectroscopic characterization, TG–DTG measurements were made in order to explore the thermal stability of these materials and develop an activation protocol for producing the unsupported catalysts. The TG–DTG curves of [N(CH3)4]4MoWS8 and NiMoWS8[N(CH3)4]4(NO3)2·6H2O are shown in Fig. 4 . A one-step mass loss and one differential thermogravimetric peak at 249°C was found in the TG–DTG curves of [N(CH3)4]4MoWS8. In contrast, a two-step mass loss and three differential thermogravimetric peaks at 64, 227, and 305°C were found from those of NiMoWS8[N(CH3)4]4(NO3)2·6H2O. These data are summarized in Table 2 . For [N(CH3)4]4MoWS8, the transition as well as the weight loss is consistent with reaction (3): (3) [N(CH3)4]4MoWS8 →2(CH3)2S2 +4(CH3)3N+MoWS4 This single step reaction (176–320°C) was proposed to involve the elimination of four molecules of methylamine (CH3)3N and two molecules of methyl disulfide (CH3)2S2. In this case, the methyl groups would react with the S2− ions of the MoS4 2− and WS4 2− units to give disulfide compounds. It is noted that we cannot rule out the presence of trace amounts of MoS4 and WS4 species in this MoWS8 precursor. However, previous TGA/DTGA results [24] show that the decompositions of the [N(CH3)4]2MoS4 and [N(CH3)4]2WS4 species occur within 226–354°C and 248–390°C. These temperatures are significantly higher than the 176–320°C range observed for the present [N(CH3)4]4MoWS8 precursor, suggesting that most of the material consists of the desired bimetallic precursor compound and not their monometallic counterparts. The decomposition mechanism of the trimetallic precursors was complicated due to the fact that nickel nitrate first reacted with the tetramethylammonium group, as shown in reaction (4): (4) [N(CH3)4]4MoWS8 +Ni(NO3)2·6H2O→NiMoWS8[N(CH3)4]4(NO3)2·6H2O Then, the transitions observed for NiMoWS8[N(CH3)4]4(NO3)2·6H2O are consistent with the following reactions: (5) NiMoWS8[N(CH3)4]4(NO3)2·6H2O→NiMoWS8[N(CH3)4]4(NO3)2 +6H2O (6) NiMoWS8[N(CH3)4]4(NO3)2 →NiMoWS4 +4(CH3)3N+(CH3)2S2 +C2H4 +2HNO3 +2S The decomposition of NiMoWS8[N(CH3)4]4(NO3)2·6H2O occurred at different temperature and two steps of weight loss were observed in Table 2. A slight weight loss was observed at low temperature in the range of 41–176°C, which is due to elimination of water, corresponding to reaction (5). From 183 to 400°C, the mass is reduced by 43.1%. Four molecules of trimethylamine ((CH3)3N), one molecule of ethylene (C2H4), two molecules of nitric acid, one molecule of (CH3)2S2 and two molecules of sulfur were directly removed during the transition process, as shown in reaction (6). The experimental result (47.5%) is consistent with the theoretical value (49.1%) for formation of NiMoWS4. 3.3 Structure of unsupported NiMoW sulfides The crystalline structure, morphology, and composition, along with surface area and pore volume, were investigated for the unsupported NiMoW sulfides. XRD patterns for the unsupported NiMoW sulfides are presented in Fig. 5 . All of the samples give weak XRD peaks, consistent with the relatively poor crystalline structures of MoS2 and WS2 (JCPDS-ICDD 37-1492, 8-0237). The presence of the (002) peak at 2θ ≈14ο is representative for the stacking slabs along the c-axis, while the presence of the (110) peak at 2θ ≈59ο is representative of a slab layer. As revealed by the XRD patterns, the intensity of the (002) peak gradually became weak as the Ni/(Mo+W) molar ratio was increased from 0 to 0.75. These results suggest that as Ni content increases, there is a decrease in the stacking along the c direction (see Fig. 5). XRD patterns of MoWS y , Ni0.5MoWS y and NiMoWS y show few impurities such as NiS x , MoO x and WO x implying that nickel is well dispersed in the prepared trimetallic NiMoW sulfides. The SSA and pore volume of the as-prepared sulfides are shown in Table 3 . Nickel content in the tetramethylammonium precursors has a significant effect on the SSA and pore volume of the sulfides. A wide pore distribution was observed in the unsupported NiMoW sulfides prepared by thermal decomposition of thiosalts. The large pore volumes, ranging from 0.41cm3 g−1 for MoWS y to around 0.05–0.08 for Ni x MoWS y , arise from the decomposition of methyl fragments, which escape from the precursor during the activation process. The reaction enthalpy has an important influence on the formation of cavities upon the decomposition of organic fragments. Cavities are formed by the accumulation of gases, while channels are created during the release of these gases [27]. In addition to the SSA and pore volume, the nitrogen adsorption–desorption curves (Fig. 6a) and pore size distributions (Fig. 6b) allow for further distinguishing of the physical structure of the materials. Above a relative pressure of 0.3–0.4, curves corresponding to type IV adsorption isotherms are observed, with desorption curves characteristic of mesoporous materials. Only Ni1.5MoWS y presents a type I isotherm, with a desorption step characteristic of microporous materials. MoWS y exhibited a well-defined hysteresis loop characteristic of a well developed porous texture. Indeed, Fig. 6b shows a narrow pore size distribution for MoWS y centered at 16nm in diameter. However, the nickel content in the thiosalt precursor strongly influences this porous texture of the final sulfides. Broad pore size distributions ranging from 6 to 18nm and 5 to 14nm in diameter were found for Ni0.5MoWS y and NiMoWS y , respectively. While Ni1.5MoWS y presented a higher SSA than the Ni0.5MoWS y and NiMoWS y samples, it has a disordered porosity by the lack of a defined pore size distribution. Comparing non-promoted MoWS y and promoted Ni x MoWS y (x =0.5, 1, 1.5), the non-promoted MoWS y has the highest specific area of about 130m2 g−1. Interestingly, the SSA first decreases and then increases with increasing nickel content in the sulfides, rather than continuously decreasing. The lowest SSA with a value of 13m2 g−1 was obtained for NiMoWS y . It has been shown that nickel species can stabilize trimetallic sulfides by incorporating in the edge planes of the (Mo–W)S structure [19]. Such Ni sites were observed in Ni-promoted MoS2 nanoclusters at the atomic scale [28]. Moreover, Bocarando et al. [29] reported that Ni atoms fully (or at least partially) substitute the Mo atoms located on the edges of Mo(W) sulfides. However, it should be noted that this behavior is prevalent at low nickel content, where generation of nickel sulfide phases is not favored. In the present case, nickel addition in the precursors has a negative effect on material textural properties, since lower surface areas were obtained upon addition. Upon increasing the Ni/(Mo+W) molar ratio from 0.25 to 0.50 (Table 3), the SSA decreases from 29m2 g−1 to 13m2 g−1. This is attributed to the formation of nickel sulfide in the pore channels of the pure Mo(W)S2 phase layer, which results in decreased sample porosity. However, when the Ni/(Mo+W) molar ratio increases to 0.75, the SSA comes up to 60m2 g−1. This is attributed to a nickel sulfide phase generated in the Ni1.5MoWS y sample, which is confirmed by the HRTEM results. This result agrees well with the structural model proposed by Wang et al. [30] for NiMoW sulfides with high nickel content. According to this model, nickel sulfide species form a continuous phase above a certain threshold nickel concentration level. Such generated nickel sulfide species with layered structure would then act as a support for Mo, W, or Mo–W sulfide particles. Finally, the particle morphology and elemental distributions in the unsupported NiMoW sulfides were investigated using electron microscopy. Fig. 7 shows SEM micrographs of the activated trimetallic NiMoW sulfides. After adding nickel promoter, the catalysts have a much more compact structure with minor formation of granules when compared with the unpromoted catalysts. Moreover, the morphology of Ni1.5MoWS y shows a more loose porous morphology with small cavities than Ni0.5MoWS y and NiMoWS y samples. Typical high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) micrographs of the Ni1.5MoWS y sample are presented in Fig. 8 , and are representative of the morphologies observed for materials derived from ammonium thiomolybdate or thiotungstate decomposition [19]. The images show a mixture of regular and irregular particles containing different phases. Typical MoS2 and WS2 fringes are visible on the sample [31], as indicated by the square in Fig. 8b. While the MoS2 and WS2 fringes appear relatively stacked, their organization is disordered. From the image, the stacking degree is estimated to be 2–8 slabs, with slab fringe lengths reaching values up to 10nm. Furthermore, crystalline lattice fringes of nickel sulfide can be distinguished from the HRTEM images (Fig. 8b, square), which may be identified as Ni7S6. Finally, Fig. 9 shows the STEM-EDX elemental maps of Ni1.5MoWS y sample obtained for sulfur, molybdenum and tungsten. From the images, it can be clearly seen that these elements are uniformly distributed throughout the unsupported sulfide catalyst. 3.4 Catalytic evaluation of unsupported NiMoW sulfides The unsupported NiMoW sulfides were evaluated for activity and selectivity for the HDS of DBT. The mechanism of this reaction over metal sulfide catalysts consists of two well-known reaction pathways: direct desulfurization (DDS) and hydrogenation (HYD). Scheme 1 shows these pathways for the HDS of DBT. In the DDS pathway, biphenyl (BP) is formed by hydrogenolysis or elimination reactions [32–34]. In the HYD pathway, the hydrogenated intermediates first are yielded, and the sulfur is then removed to form cyclohexylbenzene (CHB) and bicyclohexyl. Table 3 shows the conversions of DBT, reaction rate constants and the product selectivities obtained at 340°C and 3.0MPa. All of the samples produced three reaction products: biphenyl (BP), cyclohexylbenzene (CHB), and tetrahydro-dibenzothiophene (THDBT). The product distribution indicates that DBT is desulfurized mainly through the DDS pathway over the MoWS y catalyst, similar to sulfided Mo/Al2O3. In contrast, the results for NiMoWS y catalysts are generally different than those reported over sulfided CoMo/Al2O3 [35] and NiMo/Al2O3 [35,36] catalysts. Introducing nickel to the MoW sulfide catalysts has a significant influence on the product selectivity and conversion of DBT, as seen in Table 3. Before the addition of nickel, BP is the main product. With increasing nickel content in the sulfide catalyst, BP selectivity was reduced from 91% to 50% while CHB selectivity increased from 4% to 41%. The HYD/DDS ratio can be approximated using the equation ([CHB]+[THDBT])/[BP], and is found to increase from 0.1 to 1. The amount of nickel in the sulfide catalysts affects the DBT conversion and reaction rate constant due to induced synergetic effects in the Mo-W system. First, nickel exhibits an ability to promote Mo(W)–S interactions that enhance catalytic activity. This can be attributed to electronic effects induced by the Ni–Mo(W) interactions. Nickel causes electron density to move away from the Mo(W) atom, thus decreasing the strength of the Mo(W)–S bond. This in turn makes this bond more active for the HDS reaction. Enhanced hydrogen activation on Mo/W can also be explained by this decrease in the electronic density caused by Ni. Thus, through these effects, metal promoters increase in the number of unsaturated Mo(W) sites [37]. This effect can be particularly pronounced for catalysts presenting large areas, due to the larger number of the active sites that are exposed [22]. Perhaps most interesting from an activity standpoint is the interplay between nickel content and surface area with respect to their effects on activity. Along these lines, the Ni0.5MoWS y exhibits roughly the same DBT conversion as MoWS y (60% vs. 54%), even though the SSA of the former (29m2 g−1) is around a factor of four less than the latter (131m2 g−1). Thus, the former catalyst is intrinsically more active, as can be seen by comparing surface area-normalized rate constants (Table 3). The value of 11.2×10−8 mols−1m−2 for Ni0.5MoWS y is about 5 times as much as that for MoWS y (2.1×10−8 mols−1m−2). Thus, it can be inferred that nickel in the catalyst shows a positive effect on HDS of DBT, which more than compensates for the decrease of SSA. However, DBT conversion decreases with further increasing nickel amount from 0.5 to 1.0. This appears to be primarily due to the decrease in SSA from 29m2 g−1 to 13m2 g−1, since the intrinsic reaction rate constant only changes slightly from 11.2×10−8 to 9.3×10−8 mols−1m−2. However, surprisingly, the DBT conversion only slightly increased for Ni1.5MoWS4, even though the SSA increased by a factor of 4 over NiMoWS4. Indeed, the reaction rate constant dropped almost a factor of 4 down to 2.6×10−8 mols−1m−2 for this highest loading catalyst. This shows that an increase in SSA does not guarantee an increase in the number of active sites exposed. This is common for anisotropic layered catalytic materials, where only specific surface structures (i.e., in this case edges) provide the desired active sites. The product distributions of DBT for all trimetallic catalysts exhibit a marked difference compared with the bimetallic MoWS y catalyst. Therefore, Ni promoter modifies the selectivity to reaction products, in agreement with Daage and Chianelli. [38]. Furthermore, all trimetallic catalysts (i.e., Ni0.5MoWS y , NiMoWS y and Ni1.5MoWS y ) show increased selectivity to CHB with increasing nickel content, indicating that the HYD pathway was enhanced. One possible explanation for these changes in selectivity is the Rim–Edge model [38]. “Rim” sites located at the exterior of the stacked layers are active for hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis (C–S bond breaking), while “edge” sites located on internal stacked layers are active only for hydrogenolysis. According to this model, selectivity would change with the stacking degree of the MoS2 (WS2) particles. Thus, the decrease in the stacking degree would increase the rim/edge ratio and enhance the hydrogenation activity, as is observed here. Finally, previous studies [39] involving the unsupported MoS y and NiMoS y prepared using [N(CH3)4]2MoS4 with Ni(NO3)2·6H2O precursor resulted in significantly different results. The HDS of DBT under the same conditions in the same reactor yielded conversions of 15% and 16% for MoS y and NiMoS y , respectively. This suggests that the role of W in these materials is to enhance the activity of DBT conversion. However, the very different selectivity effects are not as obvious, and will be the subject of future investigations. 4 Conclusions NiMoW sulfides have been prepared by thermal decomposition of tetramethylammonium trimetallates obtained by mechanical grinding of dimethylammonium thiomolybdotungstates and nickel nitrate. The obtained sulfides showed cavernous morphology with type IV isotherms related to mesoporous structure, except for the Ni1.5MoWS y sample. The reaction rate constant, SSA and pore size distribution of the sulfides was influenced by their nickel content. With increasing nickel content, the layer and stacking degree of sulfide particles showed a decreasing trend. The low nickel content in Ni0.5MoWS y catalyst gave a positive effect on the HDS of DBT, as indicated by the greatly increased intrinsic catalytic activity per unit surface area. In contrast, the high nickel content in Ni1.5MoWS y catalyst showed a negative effect due to the formation of nickel sulfides. The addition of nickel promoted the hydrogenation pathway in the HDS of DBT. The Ni0.5MoWS y sample gave the highest HDS activity compared with other samples. coredata.dc:description: A family of unsupported NiMoW sulfide catalysts have been prepared by thermal decomposition of mechanically ground tetramethylammonium thiomolybdotungstate and Ni(NO3)2 for hydrodesulfurization of dibenzothiophene. The materials were characterized by Fourier transformation infrared spectroscopy, ultraviolet–visible spectroscopy, thermogravimetric analysis, X-ray diffraction, N2 physorption, scanning electron microscopy, and transmission electron microscopy. The results showed that structures and properties of unsupported NiMoW sulfides depend on nickel content and decomposition condition. XRD revealed a decrease in the stacking along the c direction of the MoS2 and/or WS2 crystalline structures as the nickel content was increased, consistent with a higher dispersion of the metal sulfides observed by electron microscopy. The low nickel content in Ni0.5MoWS y catalyst gave a positive effect on the hydrodesulfurization of dibenzothiophene, as indicated by the greatly increased specific catalytic activity per unit surface area. In contrast, the high nickel content in Ni1.5MoWS y catalyst showed a negative effect due to the formation of nickel sulfides. Ni0.5MoWS y catalyst showed the highest activity in the hydrodesulfurization reaction compared to other samples. The results further suggest that unsupported NiMoW sulfide catalysts may be promising candidates for wide application in hydrotreating of fuel oil.
coredata.dc:title: Unsupported NiMoW sulfide catalysts for hydrodesulfurization of dibenzothiophene by thermal decomposition of thiosalts
